[[File:Lester Davenport.jpg|right|thumb|Lester Davenport in 1979]]
'''Lester "Mad Dog" Davenport''' (January 16, 1932 – March 17, 2009),<ref>
{{cite web
|url=http://www.bluesinthenorthwest.com/index.php/2009/03/25/rip-lester-davenport/
|title=RIP Lester Davenport at bluesinthenorthwest.com
|publisher=www.bluesinthenorthwest.com
|accessdate=2009-03-28
|last=
|first=
}}
</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[harmonica]] player and singer.

Born in [[Tchula, Mississippi|Tchula]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]], Davenport moved from Mississippi to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], when he was 14. There he played with [[Arthur Spires]], [[Snooky Pryor]], and [[Homesick James]], then worked with [[Bo Diddley]], with whom he played harmonica on a 1955 [[Chess Records]] session.<ref name="Dead"/> He led his own group in the 1960s while he worked during the day as a paint sprayer. In the 1980s he was the harmonica player for the [[Indiana]] group [[The Kinsey Report]].<ref name="Dead"/>

In July 1994, Wolf Records released the [[Maxwell Street Jimmy Davis]] album, ''Chicago Blues Session, Vol. 11'', the tracks of which Davis had recorded in 1988 and 1989. The collection included Davenport on harmonica, and Kansas City Red playing the [[drum]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=chicago-blues-session-vol-11-r168075/credits|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( Chicago Blues Session, Vol. 11 - Maxwell Street Jimmy Davis )))}}</ref>

Davenport released his first album under his own name in 1992 and recorded a follow-up in 2002.

Davenport died in March 2009 in Chicago, from [[prostate cancer]], at the age of 77.<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2009.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed October 2010</ref>

==Discography==
*''When the Blues Hit You'' ([[Earwig Music Company|Earwig Music]], 1992)
*''I Smell a Rat'' ([[Delmark Records]], 2002)
